name: su
desc: The `su` command is a command-line tool in Linux systems used to switch user identities. It allows you to switch from one user account to another, including root user identity, without logging out. This allows you to execute commands that require specific permissions without exiting the current session.

-c.name: Execute command using a new SHELL.

-f.name: Ignore the settings in the ~/.bashrc file.

-g.name: Modify to the specified group ID.

-l.name: After logout, execute the command again after logging in.

-m.name: Similar to -l, but executed in the current directory.

-u.name: Modify to the specified user ID.

content:
Example

  • Switch to root user: su -
  • Switch to other user: su username
  • Switch to other user and use a different shell: su -s /bin/sh username
  • Switch to other user and execute specific command: su -c "command" username
